slides.title: Introduction to Guidewire Configuration
slides.notes: This lesson serves as an introduction to Guidewire configuration for developers, focusing on key components like Gosu, PCF, and the entity framework.
slides.narration: Welcome to our journey into Guidewire configuration! In this lesson, we're diving deep into the core components that make up the Guidewire framework: Gosu programming, Page Configuration Files, and the robust entity model. As we explore these elements, you'll see how they seamlessly integrate to support complex insurance operations. Let's gear up to transform how we approach Guidewire development!
slides.ocrText: Introduction to Guidewire Configuration

slides.title: Understanding Three-Tier Architecture
slides.notes: Three-tier architecture is a client-server software architecture pattern where the user interface, functional process logic, and data storage are developed as independent modules.
slides.narration: Now, let's explore the three-tier architecture that's foundational to Guidewire applications. This design separates responsibilities across the presentation, application, and data tiers, enhancing scalability and maintainability. As developers, understanding this structure allows us to effectively configure and customize each layer independently, optimizing performance and user experience.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the product architecture for

Guidewire products

Identify the primary components for
configuring Guidewire products
Explain the relationship between the
Guidewire platform and the Guidewire
applications

Demonstrate the basic functionality of
TrainingApp

Start Guidewire Studio and runa
development instance of a Guidewire
application

slides.title: Diving Into the Data Tier
slides.notes: A relational database stores operational data for Guidewire applications. The war file's database-config.xml specifies the database connection.
slides.narration: Focusing on the data tier, we see how Guidewire applications rely on relational databases to store critical operational data. The database-config.xml file plays a crucial role by defining how our application connects to this database. This separation ensures that our data remains consistent and accessible, even as we scale and evolve our applications.

slides.title: Exploring the Application Tier
slides.originalNotes:
The three-tier architecture
Three-tier architecture is a client- server software architecture pattern in which the user interface (presentation), functional process logic ("Gosu Rules"),
 computer data storage and data access are developed and maintained as independent modules. Three-tier architecture is one of the industry-standard software architectures.
slides.notes:
The three-tier architecture
Three-tier architecture is a client- server software architecture pattern in which the user interface (presentation), functional process logic ("Gosu Rules"),
 computer data storage and data access are developed and maintained as independent modules. Three-tier architecture is one of the industry-standard software architectures.
slides.narration: Shifting our attention to the application tier, this is where the magic happens. Here, Gosu rules, UI components, integration APIs, and data models come together, executed on a Java EE server. This tier is the engine of our Guidewire applications, coordinating complex business logic and integrations seamlessly. Understanding how to configure and optimize this layer is key to unlocking the full potential of our applications.
slides.ocrText:
| The three-tier architecture i

Three-tier architecture is a client-server software architecture pattern in which the
user interface, functional process logic, data storage and data access are developed
and maintained as independent modules

slides.title: The Presentation Tier Unveiled
slides.originalNotes:
Data tier
 A relational database is a collection of data structures and objects that related to each other. Databases store data in database tables. The operational data for the Guidewire application is stored inside a relational database. This database is typically hosted on a machine other than the machine hosting the Java EE application server.

The war file contains a file named database-config.xml that specifies which database to connect to and how to establish the connection.

For the latest and most complete information about the software Guidewire requires and supports, refer to the Guidewire PlatformMatrix page found at https://guidewire.custhelp.com/app/resources/products/platform-
slides.notes:
Data tier
 A relational database is a collection of data structures and objects that related to each other. Databases store data in database tables. The operational data for the Guidewire application is stored inside a relational database. This database is typically hosted on a machine other than the machine hosting the Java EE application server.

The war file contains a file named database-config.xml that specifies which database to connect to and how to establish the connection.

For the latest and most complete information about the software Guidewire requires and supports, refer to the Guidewire PlatformMatrix page found at https://guidewire.custhelp.com/app/resources/products/platform-
slides.narration: On to the presentation tier, where the user interface takes shape. Guidewire applications dynamically generate HTML pages, ensuring that the user experience is both interactive and intuitive. All navigation is handled server.side, providing a streamlined and secure interface for end-users. This design choice keeps client-side complexity low, allowing us to focus on delivering robust functionality.
slides.ocrText:

application

slides.title: Fundamental Areas of Configuration
slides.originalNotes:
Application tier
A Guidewire application consists of a set of Gosu rules, a user interface, a set of integration APIs, and a data model. The technology
 for configuring these application elements platform-level (and common to all Guidewire applications), but the specific rules, I-II, APIs, and data model for each application are distinct

All Guidewire applications are run within an application server. An application server runs enterprise-wide applications. There are several different types of application servers- The type of application server used by Guidewire applications is a Java Enterprise Edition (Java EE) server.

Each Guidewire application is built and commonly deployed as a Web Application Archive (WAR) or Enterprise Application Archive (EAR) file to the application server. It contains all the configuration, operational data and data definition files necessary to execute the application The application server is typically installed on a dedicated machine that does not host any other aspects of the architecture, such as the database.

 This machine must use an operating system supported by your third-party application server vendor (or Guidewire, in the case of Apache Tomcat). Guidewire supports the operating systems for which application servers provide customer support. For details, review the customer-viewable document Platform Matrix.

For the latest and most complete information about the software Guidewire requires and supports, refer to the Guidewire PlatformMatrix page found at https:/fguidewire.custhelp.co m/app/resourcesfproducts/platform.
slides.notes:
Application tier

 for configuring these application elements platform-level (and common to all Guidewire applications), but the specific rules, I-II, APIs, and data model for each application are distinct

 This machine must use an operating system supported by your third-party application server vendor (or Guidewire, in the case of Apache Tomcat). Guidewire supports the operating systems for which application servers provide customer support. For details, review the customer-viewable document Platform Matrix.

For the latest and most complete information about the software Guidewire requires and supports, refer to the Guidewire PlatformMatrix page found at https:/fguidewire.custhelp.co m/app/resourcesfproducts/platform.
slides.narration: Building on our understanding of the three tiers, Guidewire configuration also includes integrating with external systems. This involves configuring APIs to communicate with policy administration, billing, and claims systems, among others. Mastery of these configurations empowers us to create cohesive, interconnected applications that seamlessly align with an organization's broader technology ecosystem.

servers:

slides.title: Decoding Data Model Entities
slides.originalNotes:
Presentation tier
 Each application is a server.side application that dynamically generates a collection of standard HTML pages and data within those pages. End-users connect to the application using a web browser that renders those HTML pages. This makes only a minimal use of functionality in the client (the web browser). Because there are no static HTML files: 1) you cannot use the browser's Back button and 2) you can only bookmark the login page. All navigation is controlled on the server side.

 For the latest and most complete information about the software Guidewire requires and supports,refer to the Guidewire Platform Matrix page found https://guidewire.custhelp.com/app/resources/products/platform
slides.notes:
Presentation tier

 For the latest and most complete information about the software Guidewire requires and supports,refer to the Guidewire Platform Matrix page found https://guidewire.custhelp.com/app/resources/products/platform
slides.narration: Next, let's decode data model entities, the core building blocks of Guidewire applications. These entities map directly to database tables and are defined in XML files. Whether it's a Policy, Claim, or ABContact, each entity encapsulates critical business data. Understanding these entities is crucial, as they form the backbone of our data-driven application logic.
slides.ocrText:
| Presentation tier i

* Contains the user interface

* Each application generates a collection of standard
HTML pages that are rendered by the browser

• Modern web browsers support the Guidewire user
interface

* Chrome
« Firefox

* Microsoft Internet Explorer

* Microsoft Edge

slides.title: Gosu and Generated Java Classes
slides.notes: Generated Java classes mirror data model entities, with Gosu providing runtime business logic.
slides.narration: Here's where it gets interesting: every data model entity in Guidewire has a corresponding generated Java class, making data manipulation seamless. Gosu, Guidewire's proprietary language, complements this by enabling dynamic business logic execution. Whether managing complex processes or enhancing entity behavior, Gosu gives us the flexibility to build sophisticated applications tailored to business needs.

slides.title: Understanding PCF Files
slides.originalNotes:
Fundamental areas of configuration
 The three-tiers are the three fundamental areas of configuration There is also a fourth area of configuration for the development of integration points to external systems. Each application is typically integrated with a number of external systems. The connections to these systems are configured through the application APIs.

 Typical examples:

Policy Administration System

Billing System

Claim System

Authentication (LDAP / Active directory)

Document storage

Document production

Address Book (Contactmanagement system)

Printing System, etc..

Integration topics are discussed in Integration courses.
slides.notes:
Fundamental areas of configuration
 The three-tiers are the three fundamental areas of configuration There is also a fourth area of configuration for the development of integration points to external systems. Each application is typically integrated with a number of external systems. The connections to these systems are configured through the application APIs.

 Typical examples:

Policy Administration System

Billing System

Claim System

Authentication (LDAP / Active directory)

Document storage

Document production

Address Book (Contactmanagement system)

Printing System, etc..

Integration topics are discussed in Integration courses.
slides.narration: PCF files, or Page Configuration Format files, define how data is presented to users. These XML-based files allow us to tailor the user interface independently of the underlying data model. This separation grants us the flexibility to optimize the UI for usability, ensuring that users have a seamless interaction experience without being constrained by data storage structures.
slides.ocrText:
| Fundamental areas of configuration i
Database : Application Server : User Interface

slides.title: Components Working Together: Express Auto (1 of 6)
slides.originalNotes:
Data model entities
 A data model entity is a high-level business object used by the Guidewire application, such as ABContact, Policy, Account, Invoice, Claim. It defines the information about the object that must be stored in the database, such as Name, PubliclD, an CreateTime. It is defined in a set of one or more XML files.

In most cases, each data model entity corresponds to a table in the database. The data model entity definition defines the table structure. The fields of the entity will become columns in the database table. Each instance of the data model entity is stored as one row in the database table.

 In development environments
when the application server gets restarted or the application gets re-deployed, the database will be automatically upgraded based on the data model.
slides.notes:

In most cases, each data model entity corresponds to a table in the database. The data model entity definition defines the table structure. The fields of the entity will become columns in the database table. Each instance of the data model entity is stored as one row in the database table.

 In development environments
when the application server gets restarted or the application gets re-deployed, the database will be automatically upgraded based on the data model.
slides.narration: Let's walk through how Guidewire components work together to display information, using Express Auto as our case study. This exercise will highlight the seamless collaboration between different components of the system, from data retrieval to user display. This understanding is crucial for troubleshooting and optimizing application performance.

slides.title: Components Working Together: Express Auto (2 of 6)
slides.originalNotes:
Gosu and generated Java classes

 For every data model entity, there is a generated Java class with the same name- For every field in the data model entity, there is a field in the corresponding generated Java class. For example, the AB Contact data model entity has a "Name“ field, and the generated AB Contact Java class also has a "Name" field. In Insurance Suite, Guidewire Studio makes the process of code generation explicit and the generated code itself accessible- The generated Java class can be viewed and debugged in Studio.

When ever the application needs to work with an instance of a data model entity (which is stored as a row in the corresponding database table), the application creates an instance of the corresponding Java class- The information from the database is then read into that instance- For example, if a user searches for the ABContact whose name is "Express Auto", then the application finds the row in the database table for ABContact, creates an instance of the ABContact Java class, and reads data from that row into that instance.

 The Application Server tieralso contains Gosu resources, such Gosu classes, Gosu Rules, enhancements.

Gosu is an open-source, publicly-available programming language created by Guidewire. It is similar to Java- Gosu is used to specify runtime business logic that:

 Executes fundamental application behavior

 Manages complex business processes

Specifies dynamic client-side behavior

Gosu can be used to affect behavior throughout the product architecture. This includes:

Application (such as specifying Gosu rule behavior, methods, and entity enhancements)

Client-side behavior in the web browser (such as reflecting the change of the value in one field in some other field)

Data model behavior (such as specifying which fields to concatenate for the "display name" of a given object)

Integration behavior (such as defining the behavior of a web service that responds to requests from external applications)

Gosu is discussed in more detail in the Introduction to Gosu lesson.
slides.notes:
Gosu and generated Java classes

 For every data model entity, there is a generated Java class with the same name- For every field in the data model entity, there is a field in the corresponding generated Java class. For example, the AB Contact data model entity has a "Name“ field, and the generated AB Contact Java class also has a "Name" field. In Insurance Suite, Guidewire Studio makes the process of code generation explicit and the generated code itself accessible- The generated Java class can be viewed and debugged in Studio.

When ever the application needs to work with an instance of a data model entity (which is stored as a row in the corresponding database table), the application creates an instance of the corresponding Java class- The information from the database is then read into that instance- For example, if a user searches for the ABContact whose name is "Express Auto", then the application finds the row in the database table for ABContact, creates an instance of the ABContact Java class, and reads data from that row into that instance.

 The Application Server tieralso contains Gosu resources, such Gosu classes, Gosu Rules, enhancements.

Gosu is discussed in more detail in the Introduction to Gosu lesson.

This instance acts as the data carrier throughout the process, bridging the gap between raw data and user interface. This mechanism ensures that data is consistently and accurately represented across the application.

slides.title: Components Working Together: Express Auto (3 of 6)
slides.originalNotes:
PCF files (Page Configuration Format)

 A PCF file (Page Configuration Format) is an abstract definition of a form or location used by the user interface tier. For example, "ABContact SummaryDV" detail view is used to display information about an AB Contact. It defines the information about the objects to be displayed in the user interface, such as the Name, Public ID, Created On and Assigned User fields. It is defined in a set of one or more XML file using the proprietary PCF XML schema definition.

 There is a strong correspondence between data model entities and generated Java classes. Every data model entity has one generated Java class. There isn’t necessarily a strong correspondence between generated Java classes and PCFs. The data for one Java class could be displayed in a single PCF, or it could be displayed across multiple PCFs. The separation of the user interface tier and the application server tier gives developers the freedom to display data in whatever way makes sense to end users without being constrained by how that data is maintained in the application server or how the data is stored in the database.
slides.notes:
PCF files (Page Configuration Format)

 A PCF file (Page Configuration Format) is an abstract definition of a form or location used by the user interface tier. For example, "ABContact SummaryDV" detail view is used to display information about an AB Contact. It defines the information about the objects to be displayed in the user interface, such as the Name, Public ID, Created On and Assigned User fields. It is defined in a set of one or more XML file using the proprietary PCF XML schema definition.

 There is a strong correspondence between data model entities and generated Java classes. Every data model entity has one generated Java class. There isn’t necessarily a strong correspondence between generated Java classes and PCFs. The data for one Java class could be displayed in a single PCF, or it could be displayed across multiple PCFs. The separation of the user interface tier and the application server tier gives developers the freedom to display data in whatever way makes sense to end users without being constrained by how that data is maintained in the application server or how the data is stored in the database.
slides.narration: Next, data from the identified database row is populated into the object instance. This step is crucial as it transforms static data into a dynamic object that can interact with application logic and the UI. This transformation is seamless, thanks to the alignment between database fields and Java class attributes.

slides.narration: Stepping back, let's consider the Guidewire platform as a whole. It provides the core technology to define data models, interfaces, logic, and integration points. While each application is unique, they share this common foundation, streamlining configuration and development efforts across the suite. This shared platform is what enables us to build cohesive solutions efficiently.

Understanding these unique features helps align our configurations with business-specific needs, ensuring each application operates at its best.

slides.narration: Let's introduce the Training App, a simplified version of Guidewire's Contact Manager, designed for educational purposes. While it lacks the complexity of full-scale applications, it serves as an excellent sandbox for learning core configuration principles. As we work through exercises, we'll enhance its functionality, applying what we've learned in a controlled environment.

slides.title: Utilizing Gradle
slides.notes: Guidewire applications use Gradle for build automation, supporting incremental builds and dependency management.
slides.narration: In our development toolkit, Gradle plays a crucial role as our build automation system. With its support for incremental builds and robust dependency management, Gradle streamlines our development process. The Gradle wrapper ensures consistency across environments, minimizing version-related issues and keeping our builds smooth and predictable.
slides.ocrText:
Guidewire application-specific
functionality

slides.title: Guidewire Studio: Our IDE
slides.originalNotes:
The Guidewire platform The Guidewire platform is layer of configuration technology that includes the functionality needed to define a Guidewire applications. For example, it includes:

The technology to define a data model

 The technology to define a user interface

The technology to define application logic

The technology to define integration points

Every application uses this common technology to define own data model, user interface, business logic, and integration points. Each application is distinct, but every application shares common features and configuration techniques with all the other applications. For example, users can be created, modified or deleted the same way by the administrator in all the Guidewire applications. That is why data model entities, PCF files and application logic to manage Users are defined in the platform.
slides.notes:
The Guidewire platform The Guidewire platform is layer of configuration technology that includes the functionality needed to define a Guidewire applications. For example, it includes:

The technology to define a data model

 The technology to define a user interface

The technology to define application logic

The technology to define integration points

Every application uses this common technology to define own data model, user interface, business logic, and integration points. Each application is distinct, but every application shares common features and configuration techniques with all the other applications. For example, users can be created, modified or deleted the same way by the administrator in all the Guidewire applications. That is why data model entities, PCF files and application logic to manage Users are defined in the platform.
slides.narration: Guidewire Studio, built on IntelliJ IDEA, is our go-to IDE for development. It offers a structured environment for managing projects, configurations, and resources. With its intuitive interface and powerful tools, Studio helps us efficiently navigate and modify the complex configurations inherent in Guidewire applications, streamlining our development tasks.
slides.ocrText:
| The Guidewire platform fa
• The Guidewire platform is a layer of configuration technology that includes the
functionality needed to define a Guidewire application

• Itcontains common resources and configuration techniques that are shared by all
Guidewire applications. For example:

* Data model entities, PCF files, and application logic to manage Users
* Data model entities and PCF files to create and assign Activities to other users
• This course focuses on the Guidewire platform

Guidewire Platform offers technology for configuring

Application Integration :
Mechanisms :

slides.title: Demonstration Introduction
slides.originalNotes:
Application-specific functionality

Each application also has application-specific functionality.

The PolicyCenter-specific functionality includes:

The product model, which defines products, the policy lines assigned to each product, the coverages and coverables for the product, and the coverage terms for those coverages.

 Job flow, which defines how policy transactions (such as submissions, renewals, changes, and cancellations) are executed.

Role assignment, which defines how users are assigned responsibility for a given account, policy, or policy transaction.

 Policy validation, which validates that a given policy is valid, quotable, bindable, or issuable.
The BillingCenter-specific functionality includes:

The management of invoices over the billing cycle from planned to billed to due.

The production of producer commission statements for business collected directly from the client and the production and reconciliation of account statements where the producer collects monies due.

 The management of processing exceptions and events such as account statement queries. These are known as trouble tickets within BillingCenter.

The management of delinquency process invoked when a payment becomes overdue and the account becomes delinquent.

The ClaimCenter-specific functionality includes:

Claim financials, which includes the ability to set aside money for expected payments (reserves), the ability to issue payments (checks), the ability to track recovery opportunities, and the ability to require approval for financial activity in excess of a given user’s authority

Claim maturity, which is a set of rules that automatically manage the claim's maturity level, with particular attention paid to whether the claim can be paid out or not and whether activities should be prevented if the claim is not yet payable.

Group access, which is enforced by "Access Control Lists", that can make a claim and its sub- objects viewable or editable to only its owner, or its owner and anyone in that group, or its owner and anyone in the same security zone.

 Fraud detection, which is periodically checks claims for certain conditions and flags them for special investigation if the number and severity of the conditions it meet exceeds a given threshold.

slides.narration: Let's turn theory into practice with a demonstration. We'll work from a user story requirement, simulating a scenario where a business analyst requests a specific feature. This exercise will guide you through the process of translating business needs into technical configurations within Guidewire, reinforcing the concepts we've discussed.

slides.title: Demonstration: User Story
slides.notes: Example of a user story requirement from a fictional business analyst.
slides.narration: In this demonstration, pay close attention to how we dissect the user story to identify key configuration touchpoints. This approach mirrors real-world scenarios where developers must understand business requirements thoroughly to implement effective solutions. Watch how we navigate through Guidewire's tools to bring this request to life.
slides.ocrText:
The Guidewire training
environment

slides.title: Summary and Next Steps
slides.originalNotes:
Training App

Training App is not sold as genuine Guidewire product. It is used and maintained exclusively by Guidewire Education. The training application also has fundamental integration examples. These examples are discussed in the various Application Integration courses. Training App excludes complex functionality designed for policy billing, and claims processing.

Training App is based on Guidewire's Contact Manager application. However, much of the Contact Manager functionality has been removed or simplified to promote the learning of configuration fundamentals.

Users can search for AB Contacts on the Search tab. Once a AB Contact is selected, it is displayed on the Contact tab. Users can also create and modify different types of contacts, as Persons, Companies, Doctors, Auto Repair Shops, etc.

Training App is incomplete by design. Certain portions of the user interface have incomplete functionality. In labs, students will complete and enhance the user interface functionality of TrainingApp.

These fundamentals are the building blocks for more advanced topics. Next, we'll delve into the Introduction to the Data Model, where we'll explore how data structures underpin everything we've discussed today. Stay tuned!

slides.title: Gradle
slides.originalNotes:
Gradle
 Insurance Suite applications use Gradle. Gradle is an open-source build automation system based on a Groovy DSL (Domain Specific Language). It is a very flexible general purpose build tool.

Gradle has three phases of build development: initialization, configuration and execution. You can add source sets and add dependency configurations easily.

Gradle supports incremental builds. It intelligently determines which parts of the build tree are up-to-date so that any tasks dependent upon those parts will not need to be re-executed.

Insurance Suite applications implement the Gradle wrapper. The Gradle wrapper executes the required Gradle build on machines where Gradle is not installed. Using the Gradle wrapper enforces the usage of a particular Gradle version thus minimizing support issues.
slides.notes:
Gradle

slides.title: Guidewire Studio
slides.originalNotes:
Guidewire Studio

Guidewire Studio is an Integrated Developer Environment (IDE) based on IntelliJ IDEA. Guidewire Studio comes bundled with your application as an application project. Guidewire Studio supports the IntelliJ IDEA directory-based format (.iml) that defines the application project. The configuration-iml file defines the base project contents.

A project is the highest level of organization in Guidewire Studio and includes project- wide settings as well as collections of modules and libraries. A project is an organizational unit that represents a complete software solution. With Guidewire Studio, it is much easier to identify, work with ,manage, and version the project-related resource. In Guidewire Studio, there is almost always a I-to-I relationship between the item being configured and the underlying file that is stored on the file system. In short, the project reflects the physical file locations on the disk.

* There are limitations to working with Java classes and JAR files in a Guidewire Studio project. Creating your own Java class files directly in the Guidewire application project is not supported. You can reference specific Java classes and JARs in your project. However, there are specific requirements for how you work with your Java classes and libraries. For example, if your Gosu code references a package-local Java class, Studio will not flag this as a compile error, but the application will show the run-time error- To learn more about working with Java in the Guidewire Studio environment, refer to documentation.
slides.notes:
